I am a Principal Solutions

and today we're going to talk
about Quantum on AWS Cost Estimation.

The agenda for today will cover
the four following topics.

First of all, estimating the
cost of quantum computers,
estimating the cost of simulators,
estimating the cost of hybrid jobs,

and estimating the cost of
notebook and storage costs.

So to estimate the cost
of quantum computers,
we have to be familiar with the task
and shot model that Amazon Braket uses.
For example, users will submit tasks.
Tasks are comprised of many shots.

Each quantum computer has
a different cost for shots
and a per-task price of 30 cents.

For example, if you wanted
to submit a single task
with 10,000 shots to the D-Wave Advantage

quantum computer, the example
on the right of your screen

takes you through the
calculations involved.
So we would want to submit a single task,
and that task is gonna be comprised

of multiple shots, in
this case, 10,000 shots.
So we calculate it by the 30 cents upfront

per-task cost and the $0.00019
per-task cost times 10,000
'cause we're going to call 10,000 shots.
That gives us a total cost of $2.20.

Please note that this cost
model for quantum computers
is solely based on the number of tasks

and the number of shots
each task contains.
The next topic is the cost of simulators.

Note that this is a very
different cost model

to the quantum computer cost
model that we just covered.

In this case, we're
charged a per-minute rate,

depending on which
simulator we want to use.

In users in this case submit
tasks to the simulators,

and depending on how long
those tasks take to run

determines the price of
the final, the total cost.

For example, if we were
to use our state vector
simulator SV1 and the task took, say,
in total 30 minutes a month to run
and we ran that for an entire year,
actually we would not escape the free tier

in this case and there
would be a $0 total cost.

The free tier for simulators
is one hour per month

for the first 12 months
of Amazon Braket usage.

After that, you will be
charged a per-minute rate,

which is billed to the
nearest millisecond of usage

and the minimum is a three
second usage time slot.
You can see here in the table

the different simulators
have per-minute rates,

but they're all covered under
that 60 minutes per month
for the first year.

The next topic that
we're going to cater for
is the cost of hybrid jobs.

Hybrid jobs consist of
using classical component
and a quantum component.

What happens here is,
is that you are charged

both for the usage of
the classical instance
that runs part of your hybrid algorithm,

the number of iterations that
you wish to run that for,

and then you get into the task
shop model familiar to you
from the quantum computing section.

The entire duration of the
job is also taken into account
and the main charge there is going to be
the classical EC2 instance.

So for example, if we have
a task that is going to run

for 50 iterations, sorry, if
a hybrid job is going to run
for 50 iterations comprised of two tasks
and each one of those tasks has 100 shots,

you can see in the example
on the right of your screen

that our task charges are
going to amount to $30.
That's a fixed charge.
The shot charges are going to be $3.50
because we're running 100 shots per task,
two tasks, 50 iterations.
And then of course the classical compute
in this instance is MLP3 8X-large

and that's going to cost
$14.68 per hour to run.

We're going to run it in
this case for 26 minutes,

so therefore the cost of the
classical section is $6.36
per total of $39.86
in order to run this hybrid job,
that takes 26 minutes to run,
again, comprised of 50 iteration,
two tasks and 100 shots per task.
And in this case,

we're using the Rigetti
Aspen 11 quantum computer.

Finally, the other main
component of Amazon Braket
is notebook and storage costs.

Storage is primarily
used, primarily uses S3

to store the results
from quantum computers

and the design of algorithms
and basic data science
is all conducted in a notebook.

In this case, the notebook
instance we're going to use
is an MLC5 X-large.
Results storage, we're going to give
a conservative one gigabyte per month,
and a notebook duration per month,
let's say it's going to be eight hours
of using that notebook.

So in this case, what we
have is storage charges

of 2.3 cents for the month
because that's the cost
of a gigabyte and S3 standard,
and a utilization of eight hours
of the MLC5 X-large notebook,
which comes to a total $1.63.2 cents
for a total charge, $1.60.
That's how to estimate the cost
of your notebook and storage usage.

Obviously, if you use different
types of notebook instance,
that cost will alter accordingly,

and if you use more often
or more instances of that,
that will also multiply up accordingly.
Thank you so much for listening
